question: Malate shuttle is impoant in:
exp: Malate shuttle is more impoant in the liver and cardiac muscles as these organs require a continuous supply of energy. Whereas Glycerol-P-shuttle is a shoer shuttle and provides a quick source of ATPs as compared to the Malate shuttle. So it is present in brain & skeletal muscles, where energy is needed quickly in case of an emergency.

question: Thiamine deficiency results in decrease energy production, because TPP:
exp: Link reaction & TCA cycle requires 5 coenzymes: Lipoic acid and four B-complex Vitamins (B1, B2, B3, B5). Due to this reason, Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency results in decrease energy production (also CNS problems because Brain cells depend on this aerobic reaction) as TCA & link reaction both are responsible for energy production in cells.
opc: Is cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
opd: Interferes with Energy production from amino acids

question: Pyruvate utilisation is decreased in:
exp: PDH complex requires five coenzymes - Vitamin B1, B2, B3, B5 and Lipoic acid. Vitamin B1 deficiency - Beri-beri Beri- beri - |PDH activity - | pyruvate to acetyl-CoA conversion - low pyruvate utilization Vitamins (B1, B2, B3, B5) - decreased energy production and CNS problems (brain cells depend upon this aerobic reaction)

question: If aerobic glycolysis uses Glycerol-3-Phosphate shuttle, How many net ATPs are produced?
exp: The inner mitochondrial membrane is impermeable to NADH. Therefore, the NADH produced in the cytosol cannot directly enter the mitochondria. It enters mitochondria indirectly with the help of shuttles. e. g glycerol phosphate and malate shuttles. ATP yield in Aerobic glycolysis and Glycerol phosphate shuttle: Total ATP = 4 ATP + (-2 ATP) + 3 ATP = 5 ATP
